data.title: Sung To The Tune Of...
data.text:
(a list of songs parodied over the years

within Mad Magazine articles)

Click ▼ to toggle an article's song list and/or an example excerpt.

Click Wikipedia and YouTube icons

to open extra pages about the songs.

More to be added... Since YouTube changes constantly, please report broken links (madcoversite@yahoo.com).

ORIGINAL SONG TITLE COMPOSER / LYRICIST PARODY TITLE OR LYRIC That Old Black Magic Harold Arlen / Johnny Mercer Those Brand New Gadgets Oh Give Me a Home (Home on the Range) Daniel E. Kelley / Dr. Brewster M. Higley Oh Give Me a Phone Baby Face Harry Akst / Benny Davis Baby Sit The Girl Next Door Hugh Martin and Ralph Blane The Folks Next Door The Anniversary Song Ion Ivanovici / Al Jolson and Saul Chaplin East Side, West Side Charles B. Lawlor / James W. Blake Oh, What a Beautiful Mornin' Richard Rodgers / Oscar Hammerstein II Oh, What a Beautiful Beefsteak It's All Right With Me Cole Porter To Get More Salary The House I Live In Earl Robinson On the Sunny Side of the Street Jimmy McHugh / Dorothy Fields There's a Rumble Down the Next Street Three Coins in the Fountain Jule Styne / Sammy Cahn Three Cards in My Wallet

"...We believe in any event that the parody lyrics involved in this appeal would be permissible under the most rigorous application of the 'substantiality' requirement. The disparities in theme, content and style between the original lyrics and the alleged infringements could hardly be greater. In the vast majority of cases, the rhyme scheme of the parodies bears no relationship whatsoever to that of the originals. While brief phrases of the original lyrics were occasionally injected into the parodies, this practice would seem necessary if the defendants' efforts were to 'recall or conjure up' the originals; the humorous effect achieved when a familiar line is interposed in a totally incongruous setting, traditionally a tool of parodists, scarcely amounts to a 'substantial' taking, if that standard is not to be woodenly applied. Similarly, the fact that defendants' parodies were written in the same meter as plaintiffs' compositions would seem inevitable if the original was to be recognized, but such a justification is not even necessary; we doubt that even so eminent a composer as plaintiff Irving Berlin should be permitted to claim a property interest in iambic pentameter."

Circuit Court Judge Irving Kaufman

in Berlin v. E.C. Publications, Inc.
